At 23:10 26/08/2004, you wrote:
>Ian Badcoe wrote:
>
> >This question of the shape and size of fitness landscapes is one that has
> >intrigued me for years.  I have a few intuitions about them which you might
> >like to argue with:
> >
> >1) They're big.  And for any really interesting question (like how to play
> >chess) they're not big like the universe is big, they're _much_ larger than
> >that.
> >
> >
>Also, quite often they have a lot more than 3 dimensions.

Oh yes, did I not mention that ;-)

But....  acherly the number of dimensions is a thing that gets fuzzy as the 
case gets complex.

For example, consider a human being (you probably have one around the place 
somewhere).  You can call the human genome a point in a 3,000,000,000 
dimensional search space.  On the other hand:

1) each "dimension" in that space has only 4 possible values (CGTA)
2) (or in a different view) since evolution can add to the size of the 
genome, the space is "infinitely dimensional"
3) (but then again) the dimensions are not really distinct, since I can 
transpose a whole gene somewhere else in the genome without changing its 
"meaning"
4) (but) if we ignore the "junk DNA" then the space is much small, say 
150,000,000 dimensions
5) (however) in a codon, the last base rarely changes the amino-acid coded, 
so roughly 1/3 of all dimensions have no effect
6) (and anyway) if we take the amino-acid residue view then instead of 
150,000,000 4-choice dimensions, we have 50,000,000 20-choice dimensions
7) (but anyway) most of the amino-acids can be changed without altering the 
protein's function (a few are critical, others just need to retain rough 
size or hydrophobicity)
8) (and even then) I would characterize the really interesting "different 
places" in this space as the high-points of remote optima (or the whole 
"fit enough" regain around each optimum).  e.g. the whole region for 
"human" vs. the whole region for, say, "alligator".  The existence and 
separation of these regions is largely independent of how many dimensions 
we visualize the space in [although I might suggest that a visualization 
which leaves the whole human meta-optimum in a single locality was better 
than one that spread it all around...]

         Ian Badcoe
